body.p:
I am just in receipt of the Occidents
which your kind direction caused to be forwarded
to me with unusual dispatch & I hasten to
offer you many thanks for your kindness in
calling my attention to the advertisement of the
Charleston Congregation. I trust you will par-
-don my freedom in trespassing further upon your
goodness, but for many reasons I am undisposed
to take a plunge in the dark & discover too late
that my impetuosity has been unwise. I am thus
led to obtain as much information as possible
concerning the place & people—labors & emoluments
as regards the place my principal fears are on ac-
-count of climate Mrs Mendes's health suffered
from her residence in Jamaica & if, as I have heard,
Charleston is as bad, I could never think of expo-
-sing her to the influence of such a climate. The people
cannot possibly be more unacceptable than those among
whom I live, but if they should possess the vascillating?
character I have heard ascribed to several American
congregations, I should be unwise to exchange the
ills I bear for those I know not of. I have however
a longing to be again in a Portuguese Cong.—that could
lead me very far, & I fear would blind me against
many inconveniences. In respect to the labors and
emoluments of the office, I shall prosecute my
inquiries elsewhere, but will only trouble you for any

information you can afford me about the leads mentioned
above, especially the nature of the climate, extent of win
=ter, influence upon Europeans. If you could kindly add
any intelligence concerning the cause of Mr Jacob's resig
-nation, & also any hints respecting the cost of living
in Charleston, ?, domestics &c; —I should feel
extremely obliged. Before quitting this subject let
me iterate my apologies, for obtruding such questions
upon your valuable time & attention; but as I recog
-nize in your goodness which secured to me early in-
-formation of the situation, an evidence of kind interest
I have presumed upon it as above. Be however assured
that I shall be happy to retaliate the service in any
way that I can be of use to you now or hereafter.

I have read with delight your remarks
on the Press & pulpit, those two great teachers of
society, capable of achieving such vast results, for good or
for evil. Alas that I should have to point to any
congregation of my people as an evidence of this last
assertion, but let the communities of Cincinatti prove
how holy things can be defiled through the infamous
agency of a Pulpit filled by & a Press directed by men
without principle. But I for one must say I
dont fear these men & apprehend no permanent evil
as the result of their blasphemies. Hebrew
I firmly believe that the end of all such movements
is the reaction in favor of orthodoxy—that pure
religion which has not survived the sword & the stake, to
perish before the neological madness of a few ununprinci

I have read your translation of the Bible with
real satisfaction & I deeply regret that the price (10/6)
must militate against its general introduction in our
schools. I have tried to bring it to the notice of seve
ral gentlemen;—but have only succeeded in two in
-stances. I regret to say that men who cheerfully
give half a guinea for a night's amusement, think
that sum too much for God's word faithfully presented.

I some time since asked you to indicate a means
of forwarding a copy of my sermons, lately published
but you omitted to reply on that head. I however
send you a copy by the present opportunity & shall
feel obliged for your candid—unreserved opinion. I
value your character eminently as “the man of sincerity”
& I am sure you could not under the fear of wounding
an author's pride withold your judgment.

Allow one to congratulate you on your being again in
office among our people. I feel indeed that no office
can add prestige to the name of Isaac Leeser, unad?
though that be by the questionable dignity of Dr or “Rabbi”
but there can be no doubt that a wider field & a more
extended privilege are opened before the minster than be
-fore the man. May the Eternal spare your useful life for many years, that you may live to see
the downfall of infidel reform & the triumph all
over the world of Hebrew.
With best respects I am, Dr Sir,
